summary: This is a legal reply memorandum filed by The New York Times Company in its FOIA lawsuit against the Federal Bureau of Prisons. The document argues that the BOP has failed to justify withholding approximately 3,500 pages of records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and suicide under various FOIA exemptions. The Times seeks summary judgment to force disclosure of these records. This is a legal brief filed by The New York Times Company in a FOIA lawsuit against the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) seeking documents related to suicide prevention procedures and the death of Jeffrey Epstein. The plaintiff argues that BOP has not properly justified withholding the requested documents under FOIA exemptions and asks the court to order their disclosure.

events.title: Filing of Plaintiff's Brief
events.description: The New York Times Company files its legal brief in FOIA lawsuit seeking documents related to BOP suicide prevention procedures and Epstein's death.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center New York, New York
United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The BOP is withholding approximately 3,500 pages of records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and suicide, citing FOIA Exemptions 7(A), 5, 6, 7(C), and 7(E).

The withheld records include emails about Epstein's mental/physical health, details of his incarceration, reports on his suicide attempt and death, correspondence with his cellmate's attorneys, and Epstein's medical/psychological records.

The BOP claims disclosure could interfere with the prosecutions of Nicholas Tartaglione (Epstein's former cellmate) and two correctional officers accused of failing to perform counts when Epstein died.
The New York Times argues the records are administrative, not compiled for law enforcement, and that the public's interest in understanding BOP's failures outweighs any privacy concerns.
The document references Epstein's brother publicly calling for BOP to produce records related to the suicide, contradicting the BOP's claim of a privacy interest.
The New York Times Company is suing the Bureau of Prisons under FOIA for documents related to suicide prevention procedures and Jeffrey Epstein's death.
The plaintiff argues that BOP has not adequately justified withholding documents under FOIA exemptions, citing publicly available information about suicide prevention procedures.
The legal brief references prior case law (Coleman v. FBI, Shapiro v. Dep't of Justice) regarding when investigative techniques can be protected from disclosure.
The plaintiff seeks a court order declaring the documents public, requiring disclosure within 20 business days, and awarding attorneys' fees.
The document is part of Case 1:20-cv-00833-PAE in the U.S. District Court.
